- Keep improving Authenticator GUI (Modern, Responsive Animation to touch and clicks)

What is the point of installing an MFA on your computer? Basically if someone has compromised your computer with access to you username and password, they now also have your second factor authentication!

description:
I tried this app with good expectations despite the bad reviews. However, I was disappointed enough to uninstall the same day.

For one thing, the "Preferences" screen has no "X" icon, which means I can't X out unless I use the Alt+F4 shortcut or quit from the taskbar.

Moreover, the app offers the option to export the OTP secret password used to generate the 6-digit codes in a PLAIN TEXT file, with no encryption and no password needed. Although the app supports a startup password, the file that is exported doesn't require this password to open. This should have been better thought-out, as the output file could easily be encrypted with the startup password.

Finally, as another reviewer pointed out, the QR code scanner feature doesn't work on my system (which uses Wayland rather than Xorg).

There are certainly better Linux authentication apps than this one out there, ones that work more smoothly and have better security measures. This app works, but not like it ought to work.
summary: Unfortunately, the app is buggy and lacks security

Great integration with gnome 40 on fedora 34. Scanner works flawlessly. Dark theme works out of the box. Option to lock the app. I use this for all of my important accounts in combination with KeepasXC for my passwords and 2FA codes
Whatever I do, I couldn't make it work. Use OTPClient. Much reliable, can do encrypted backups and restore. This is just not nice. Highly disappointed.
